text.0: @crstamps2 @fleccas Great question! Our colleagues at @PolitiFact fact-checked this and rated it false. Read the full fact-check here: https://t.co/QPhuWEaNCR
text.1: Regardless of how #Election2020 ends, it’s critical that you remain diligent in stopping the spread of misinformation. Be intentional about how you consume information and #ThinkBeforeYouShare.
text.2: During elections, everyone seems to become a political analyst :chart_increasing:. Keep in mind that celebrities and influencers are NOT experts. Make sure you’re getting your information from credible outlets like @AP or local election officials.
text.3: A lot of you are eager to read and share #Election2020 results. We get it. But it’s important to remember that this is a developing story. Before you click the share button, pause :pause_button_selector: for a second. Does the content you’re sharing cite sources?
text.4: You might be wondering why some news orgs have declared winners of the presidential election in battleground states and others haven’t. Remember: different outlets have different methods for calling races. More on that here: https://t.co/FTtf5NIXU6
text.5: Make sure you’re getting your information from AT LEAST 3-4 reliable sources. News orgs are a great place to start. The more outlets that confirm a story, the more trustworthy the information is.
text.6: The reporting on #Election2020 results is changing FAST. With votes still being counted in key battleground states, it’s important to know how to get the facts. :thread:
